tier.item: Other morphological case languages, e.g. Finnish and Russian, also offer evidence that
nominative case is sometimes licensed VP-internally.
Yip et al. 1987 give the Acc-Nom example Mig sækir syfja ("me(A) gets sleep(N)",
meaning `I am getting sleepy'). It has, however, an unclear and a questionable status.
Gen-Nom is found in certain predicative constructions (e.g. Hans er bráðum von, "his(G) is
soon expectation(N)", meaning `He is expected to arrive soon').
Other morphological case languages, e.g. Finnish and Russian, also offer evidence that
nominative case is sometimes licensed VP-internally.
Yip et al. 1987 give the Acc-Nom example Mig sækir syfja ("me(A) gets sleep(N)",
meaning `I am getting sleepy'). It has, however, an unclear and a questionable status.
Gen-Nom is found in certain predicative constructions (e.g. Hans er bráðum von, "his(G) is
soon expectation(N)", meaning `He is expected to arrive soon').
Other morphological case languages, e.g. Finnish and Russian, also offer evidence that
nominative case is sometimes licensed VP-internally.
Yip et al. 1987 give the Acc-Nom example Mig sækir syfja ("me(A) gets sleep(N)",
meaning `I am getting sleepy'). It has, however, an unclear and a questionable status.
Gen-Nom is found in certain predicative constructions (e.g. Hans er bráðum von, "his(G) is
soon expectation(N)", meaning `He is expected to arrive soon').

tier.item: (62) Þeim hefur/*höfum alltaf fundist [við vinna vel].
This applies to the standard "dialect"; some speakers find agreement deviant or
ungrammatical in examples of this sort.
them(D) has/*have always found we(N) work well
`They have always thought that we work well.'
